text:
- Welcome to the Executive
Insights podcast,
brought to you by AWS.

I'm Clarke Rodgers, Director
of Enterprise Strategy,
and I'll be your guide

through a series of conversations
with security leaders.

My guest today is Tom
Scholl, Vice President
and Distinguished Engineer at AWS.
In our discussion today,
it's all about network security.
We discuss DDoS mitigations,
how AWS thinks about threat intelligence
and some of the tools we build,

such as MadPot that helps
disrupt criminal organizations

as well as working at the size
and scale of the AWS network.
Please enjoy.
Tom, thanks so much for joining me
on Conversations with Security Leaders.
- Hey, thanks for having me.
I'm happy to be here.

- Could you please describe
your role a little bit
and then specifically what it is
to be a distinguished engineer at AWS?

- I work in our
infrastructure organization

where I primarily focus on
our network infrastructure.

So that means the network
in our data centers,

our global backbone,
our edge infrastructure,

how that connects to
and from the internet,

as well as deal with
things like DDoS defense,
as well as the disruption of that
and generally network abuse type issues.
And as a distinguished engineer,

I think one of the things
that's really important
is being in the details.

You're not in an ivory tower.
You actually have to have

and maintain proficiency for
your area and your domain,

and knowing how things
work, being able to go deep,
being able to engage at all levels
of individual contributors and managers,

and being able to understand
rapidly what's going on
and make the right recommendations.
Working on a variety of areas in terms

of product development as
well, cross organization,
and engaging with customers as well.
- And what about your previous life?

So you've been with AWS
now about 13 years or so.
What about your previous experience
made you prepared for this role?
- So I worked in the ISP
and telecom space for over a decade.

And so a lot of that work was
involved in building networks
and operating them at a global scale.
So I think having that knowledge,
really applied here,

in addition to when
you work in that space,
when it comes to working
and connecting to other internet networks,
the internet peering ecosystem,
you build a lot of relationships as well.

So understanding how the
true internet really works,

how networks actually
operate with each other,

and other things that
come along with that,
such as security topics.
So that really prepared me

for addressing the scale
and needs on the AWS side.
- I'm glad you brought up security.

As you know, this is "Conversations
with Security Leaders,"

but you're not actually
on the security team,
you're focused on networking.
What about your interest in networking

also drew some interest into
the security aspects of it?

I understand you focus a
lot on DDoS protections
and other abuses of networks.

- In working in the networking
space for a long time,
building networks, supporting them,

one of the things that was
always really passionate to me

was making sure that as
you're building networks,
routers, things like that,
they have to be secure.

No one should be able
to SSH to your routers,

your network infrastructure
has to be rock solid.
And that really comes down
to having multiple layers of defense.

And over the years also,
looking at other areas
of internet route security,
which has been a thing

that's always been an area
that needed to be addressed.
So it was always something core to me,

and it wasn't until at least
the last several years ago
where I started to look into
the world of DDoS a bit more.
I started diving into that area

and immersing myself in the
world of how DDoS operates,
different types of abuse,
and really jumping into that ecosystem

and learning from others and
then taking that information
and applying it to how can we do better.

- So working at AWS,
has there been anything
that has really surprised you

about the scale of AWS from
a networking perspective?
- Yeah, definitely.
The network is a lot larger.
The diversity in terms of customers,
what types of their use cases,
continually surprises me.

So we have that infrastructure
that people can build upon.

And so you see a variety
of different use cases

like anybody else,
attacks do come inbound.
So we get to see that,
we get to see how they grow over time,
how they iterate and improve
and we can respond to that in real time.

And we have different
systems that do that.
So with the AWS scale,

it definitely gives you
a lot more visibility
into what sort of threats are out there.
- Can you talk a little bit more about,
I guess, some of the motivations around
some of the bad actors that are out there
who commit DDoS against companies?
- There's a variety of reasons,.
So one of them can be focused on gaming.

Someone wants to disrupt
a game, for example,
sometimes it could be e-learning.
They want to disrupt a classroom.

Like during Covid, there was
a lot of e-learning going on
at that time, and so people would want to
not go to school as it were.

- So pranks.
- Yeah, well,
I mean there's still malicious
and they still cause damage.

But all the way into targeting
financial institutions,

banking, online marketplace
type operations,
shopping, to just showing off

and demonstrating, doing
what they call power proofs.

So there's a wide variety
of why people attack things.
And there's an industry called the

DDoS-as-a-service industry
that basically caters to that

and provides that
infrastructure for people
to go pay and launch attacks.
- Tell me more about that.

- Yeah. They call them
booters or stressors,
and it's typically you pay in crypto
and you can target
and specify where you want to attack.
These storefronts will also show off

and say, "Here's snapshots of
what we've hit in the past,"
to demonstrate

to their customers that
this is what you get.
And sometimes these folks,
they run their own infrastructure,

sometimes they buy and
resell API access to others
to run it through somebody else.
So they're almost like resellers.
So it's a whole industry out there.
There's several,

I'd say dozen of them
operating at any given time.

And that's where the
majority of DDoS attacks

really get originated
from these storefronts.

- Well, let's go ahead
and dive into it now.
You recently were involved with a group
called Anonymous Sudan.

Can you tell us a little
bit about that story?
- Yeah, Anonymous Sudan was another DDoS,
as a service provider.
They were launching attacks
and providing access to people

to use their infrastructure
to launch attacks.
And one of the systems
that we built internally called MadPot,

it's a honeypot service
which has the ability
to identify these attacks

and actually see the true
infrastructure behind it,
the actual true sources of it.

And they, like many
other actors we identify,

it just was yet another
DDoS-as-a-service provider

that we were able to
identify the infrastructure
and collaborate with industry peers on
in terms of taking that further,
and in terms of mitigation.
- You had mentioned MadPot.
Is MadPot just a internal service
for AWS to use?
How do customers benefit from that?

- So the information that
we get out of MadPot is,
we see a lot of threat actors,

different exploitation
activity, mass scanning.

Things like that get
collected up by MadPot
and we could take a lot of the data
that we collect out of that
and we could turn that around
into directly helping our customers
from a security perspective
and availability perspective as well.
And so what's key about MadPot is
it gives us a vantage point
to not only give us visibility

into denial of service
infrastructure that's out there,
but it also finds people attempting
to do these sorts of activities.
We can feed that back into other systems,
such as WAF,

to use it to protect
customers, network firewall,

as well as some other things
that go behind the scenes.

Recently we talked about
something called Sonaris, right,

which is a system that gets
some of its data from MadPot

that says, "This
particular set of resources

are scanning all these
customer resources."
We can go and block that activity
without anyone knowing about it.

So that MadPot system
basically funnels into moving
the needle on a variety of different areas
when it comes to protecting customers
and using AWS services.

- How do systems like
MadPot come to fruition
inside of AWS?

I imagine someone said,
"Hey, there's a problem,

here's a way we can
fix it moving forward."
- [Tom] Sure, yeah.

Another engineer who's
a principal engineer
in my organization,
he originally came up with the idea.

And it originally was
focused on high interactions
and capturing threats.
And it was actually just a few years ago
that he and I were talking
and we said, "We could really pivot this
to also address DDoS."

And to us we're like, "Yep,
we can add these other ways

that we can detect the
different pillars of DDoS
that are out there."
There's several of them that operate
in terms of IP spoofing, botnets,
Application Layer 7 request floods.
And we were able to quickly iterate
and it was a case

where we didn't have
to ask for permission,
we just moved forward and did it.
And we immediately saw the value of it

and it was like, "Great,
we've got this data."

And then it was like, "Well,
do we just want to see it?"

And I was like, "No, let's
actually do something

and actually, let's engage
externally with networks
where a lot of this stuff is originating
and directly try to mitigate it upstream."
So it was definitely something
that was naturally born and evolved
and we've continued to iterate over time
and we will continue to do so.
- That's fantastic.
And I imagine even though we can't talk
about a lot of them,
there are other services in the works
that are doing similar things
on behalf of customers as well.

- Sure, yeah, no, there's
a number of things.
When we look at MadPot, Sonaris,
Mithra, we're continuing to improve

on how do we leverage
different types of technology,
for example, using gen AI

and how we look at that for
some of our deception technology

that we use in MadPot of how
do you build a better honeypot?

How do you make it so
it doesn't look obvious?

And how do you make these
things look very unique
and something that would really attract
a threat actor to interact with?
In addition to other technologies
of how do you build a better way
to detect different attack signals?
How do you get the anomalous,
take the signal out of the noise

and basically use that to
apply better mitigations,
for example.

- As part of your role as a
distinguished engineer,
the job is to sort of poke around AWS

and say, "Are you all
doing the right thing
at the right time for the right reasons?"

When you see something
that's not in alignment

with what you believe
to be the right thing,
how do you point that out

and have that conversation
with the leaders of that team?
Or maybe it's an individual.

- First thing I usually
do is actually engage
with the team directly.

And that's really to learn and
understand what's going on.

I just don't want to throw
an escalation over the top.
I actually do want to engage with the team

and the senior folks on the
team to actually understand
what's actually going on

and being able to extract
clarity and truth out of that.

And then depending on
where that needs to go,
it's like, "Okay, this is something
where we may have to escalate,

bringing data, being
clinical about what it is,

and then having that conversation
with their leadership,

and then maybe that expands
out further from there.
Because a lot of times you find out that
sometimes things got in a particular way,
there's a story behind it.
Sometimes you have to empathize,

to understand how things
came into a particular area.
And so you have to recognize that.
And sometimes there's some history there.
But a lot of it is
bringing that data out of it,
that clarity out of it,
being able to explain it, explain,

"Hey, this is what I
think we should be doing.
Here are maybe some of the other options.

Here's why we didn't choose
those particular options."
And then basically pushing
that conversation forward,
but at the same time,
being balanced and pragmatic about it.
You have to understand, hey,

some things can maybe be
done in the short term.
Some of these things may real project work
that require investment.

But yeah, it all starts from
directly at going to the team

and then expanding out
from there as required

- And understanding
that it's everyone's job
to lean into these things.
- Yeah, for sure.

Certainly as senior
technical leaders, that is

the expectation that you do
go and look around corners
and you find things.
And if you see something that doesn't
look right, raising that.
- You mentioned escalation.
Can you talk a little bit about AWS
or Amazon's escalation culture?

- Yeah, no, it's definitely
one of the things

that I found when coming
from other companies
coming to AWS that I really liked a lot.

The concept of if you do see
something that isn't right,

you own it until you find
out who actually does.
And I think that that level of escalation,
it's not frowned upon.

If you're escalating
for the right reasons,

no one will ever look poorly
on that. It's encouraged.

And I think coming from
other companies where

you may see the attitude
of, "That's not my job.

That's someone else."
Or, "Hey, let it fail."
That wasn't the culture here.
And I really enjoyed that a lot.

And that idea of that,
"Hey, if I see something,

I can bring it to the right people,
I can ask questions."
And we encourage that around folks.
And if I don't think the answer is right,
eventually taking that further.
And it may end up in a case

where it's a have backbone,
disagree and commit,
because another part I think
that also touches on is ownership.
We want to push down ownership
to the individual teams.

And this is another thing where
working at other companies,

I've been in the role where
the technical decision
to use a particular platform or hardware
was made outside of the team

that actually has to run
it at the end of the day.

And being able to come
to AWS, it was like,

"You're the one with
the pager. You own it."
You get to make a lot of those decisions.
So I think that is another part aspect too
that's a strong part of AWS

but definitely I'd say
escalations is something that's
encouraged to get ownership
and the right things happening,
as well as that concept around ownership
of the people who own these things,

they get to make the
decisions for their space.
- And it's not an aspect of,
"Let's get somebody into trouble."

It's to actually solve
the issue for a customer
or for the company at large.
- Right, Yeah.
You take the people part out of it.

It's just like, "Hey, I
think there's an issue here.
This doesn't sound right.
We need to dig into this."

And it could be a variety
of different topics
that get into it,
but it's really coming from

the intent of, "I think
there's something wrong here
and I want to get more eyes on it.

Let's have the discussion
and drive it forward."
And so I think people are encouraged

when you see that stuff
in different places,

whether it be a customer
issue, a customer escalation,

or something that a
metric doesn't look right,

people are encouraged to take
it to the next level and,

"Okay, this team's running
with it, they're on top of it.
Okay, good. I can disengage,
make sure the right things happen."
- That's awesome.

So Tom, running networking
inside of AWS is,
it's a business within a business.
How do you demonstrate

and report the value of
what you all are doing
to senior management?
- So I think the main thing, from wherever
that particular area may be is,
does that team have the right tenets?

Are they thinking about the
problem in the right way?

And from that, does the
team have the right,
I would say, goals and and metrics

and mechanisms in place
to really measure that?
And so when it comes to the security
and particularly these sorts
of defensive type solutions,
how do you prove the value of this thing
that's going to be blocking things?
And so being able to actually come up
with the right mechanisms and metrics
to measure that to say, "Okay,

if we weren't doing this,
this would've happened."
So it's really important,
I think as a team is instantiated,
to have the right kind of setup,
know who their customers are,
making it very clear.

So I think it's all about
having the right setup there
and being able to show that
and iterating on that over time.
It certainly as the scope expands,
are there areas that we need to invest in
that we aren't today?

And so bringing clarity
to that too, as well.
We have a very document driven culture,
so being able to explain that,
where somebody can actually understand

and actually put the
pieces together to say,
"I see what you're bringing here."

- You mentioned tenets.
Tell me more about tenets.

- So tenets really guide
a team and dictate,

"This is what's important to
us and this is how we operate."

And it really is the
building blocks of a team

to really express, "This
is what's important to us.

This is what we're going to
do. This is what we own."

And I think having that
really crisply defined

for a team really steers
them down the right course.
- That's fantastic.
Let's switch gears a little bit to more
of the sort of human side of things.
Your networking team,

and then broadly the AWS
security team as well,

when you're looking to
hire for a new role,
an open engineering role on your team,
what are you looking for?

- So I would say one of
the things is definitely,

and this comes back to some
of our leadership principles.

So if you look at them, there's
really great ones out there.

One of the things I really look
for is learn and be curious.
And I think it's looking for talent that
wants to ask the deeper question of,

"Hey, why is something the
way it is? Can we do better?

I have an idea, how can
I proof of concept that?"
And looking for that sort of...
Not settling for the way things are
and looking forward and also willingness
to get outside your comfort zone.

To say, "I'm going to immerse
myself in something new
and try to figure it out,

and maybe I could bring a
different perspective to it.
I'm willing to pull into the work."
I think that's certainly one area
that I certainly look for, for sure.

- And once that person is then
hired and is on your team,
what kind of mentorship opportunities
do they typically have?

Because again, when Tom
joined 13 years ago,
probably his eyes were wide open saying,
"Oh my gosh, AWS is huge."
I imagine that's not out of the norm.

So how do you help new
engineers understand
how everything's going on
at the scale which they're operating?

- I mean, definitely through
mentorship and guidance,
pointing them to the particular areas
of whether that's people to talk to,

to say, "Hey, you're
interested in this thing,
go talk to this particular person.
They're a subject matter expert into it."
Or if it's just even direct,

"Hey, I could explain
to you how this works.

I think another one is
presenting opportunities.
So in the back of my head I can rattle off

lots of different things
that I've been curious about

that, "Hey, I think we
need to pull at the thread
on this a bit more."
So providing opportunities to say,

"Hey, this is an area maybe
you could take a look at,"

or, "Here's several. Why
don't you lean into one

for a bit? And I can
help you along the way
through that journey."

But I think taking that and
then also, at the same time,

as these people are
growing and developing,
amplifying their voice where you can,

like, "Hey, you found
something. Let me help
steer you and amplify what you're trying
to say or get some additional attention,"

and guidance on communication,
things like that.

- So it sounds like as a
distinguished engineer,
not only are you a subject matter expert,
but you're also a coach.
- Yeah, no, definitely.

And not only just for
individual contributors,

but also certainly on the
management side as well.

So I think you have to
recognize that you have to deal
with both types of sets of folks
and managers how they manage the team.
And as a manager's managing team, "Hey,
how are you looking at your folks?
Who's working on what?
Are people lined up?
Are they set up for success?"
So you have to do it on both sides
and look at managers.
And then that extends into org design

and how are we thinking
about how we organize people?
Are we working on the right things?
Is the ownership aligned correctly?

So you're kind of all over
the place a bit. Yeah.
- Tom, when you're not internally focused,
you also have the opportunity to meet
with lots of customers.

Are there any areas that
particularly stand out with you

when you're having the
networking conversations
with customers?
- So it's networking,
I would say also the security
and DDoS one come into it too as well.
And so from a networking perspective,

we have a number of products
that we've launched recently
that provide a lot more visibility
into network monitoring and availability

that I'd definitely encourage
customers to take a look at.
When it comes from the security,
particularly like the DDoS one,
I think it's really important
having a strong front door.
If you have a presence on the internet,

making sure that how you're
exposing your resources,
public IP addresses,
that you really want to make sure
that you have strong front doors there.
And that's where it's,
"Are you using our CDN CloudFront?
Do you have WAF enabled?
Do you have ShieldAdvanced?

Okay, if you're on
application load balancer,
do you have WAF enabled there?

Do you have a good accounting
of all your public resources?
And understand...

Do you have the right
security controls there?
And I think that's really important,

particularly since I
deal on the DDoS side.
There's a lot of things where
customers need to understand that
even in cases where they do use a CDN,

"Hey, your origin happens
to live inside of EC2.

Is your origin set up
to only allow CloudFront
to talk to it?"
Because there are people out there

that will know that
it's in front of a CDN,
they will try to scan
and find your resources in EC2
and say, "Ah, this is the true origin.

I'm going to bypass this
and go for that thing."
You need to follow best practices there

to make sure that you're
buttoned up completely.

- As you know, over the
last 18 months or so,

generative AI has been in
the news all over the place.

Where do you see generative
AI playing a role
in the networking space?
- We definitely use it
for productivity improvements there
in terms of helping engineers
to find really difficult sets of data
that's out there

and that would otherwise
take a fair amount of time.

And so there's been a number
of generative AI tools

that have been developed to
basically allow people to

like, "I need to get at
this particular set of data,
what kind of queries do I need to run?"
And it'll go and write the code for them.
And so I've seen that
and it's pretty amazing the stuff

that it's been able to build,
where it's just like...

If you had to do this by
hand, it'd take some time.
So there's things like that.
There's other items like ticket summaries,
being able to really summarize things
and making it crisp there.
But I've seen, certainly on the
networking/engineering/operations side,
it would basically be a time reducer,
cutting the things down
from beginning to end of where different

folks of different proficiency
maybe can do it faster
because they have the right muscle memory.
But I've seen it really equalize

and make it easier for
people to get at data
on the networking side specifically.
And then for security, as we mentioned,
using it for building better honeypots,
improving our deception capability
to make things really look unique

and something that would
really attract attention
as well as identifying attack signals

and coming up with more
effective mitigations
and getting the signal out of the noise.

- Tom, thanks so much
for joining me today.
- Okay.
Thank you for having me.
